section.text: Good morning everyone. The first question will be on revenue, both the organic and the change in your fiscal 2024 targets. Just curious, Carl, in your comments, you talked about macroeconomic issues, particularly there seem to be some challenges in Europe, et cetera. And I'm curious how you're thinking organic is going to perform, especially with some of your businesses overseas in light of these economic conditions.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory Peters", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "bbd5b1e4-283f-4033-b3a8-3c64fc745809", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Raymond James"}

section.text: And then if I think about the fiscal 2024 target, the revised target, it implies a compound annual growth rate of 5% or a little bit higher. And that's not something that's happened very often in the history of Willis Towers Watson. So just trying to bridge the gap between what's going on in the macro environment and what you're suggesting is potential for the company.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Gregory Peters", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "bbd5b1e4-283f-4033-b3a8-3c64fc745809", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Raymond James"}

section.text: Yes. Sure, Greg. So I look at it this way, across our key growth drivers, which include strategic initiatives, hiring and industry conditions, we do see momentum building that gives us confidence in achieving the targets we've laid out. Our strategic growth initiatives are gaining traction, for instance, we're making progress on scaling our global lines of business and corporate risk and broking.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "e727504d-f5a3-4ee5-b017-6b98c05cc78e", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: And we do expect the growth in these lines is going to continue to exceed the CRB average material. And we're also seeing a steady pace of new product launches, and we're focusing on high growth and high need markets like ESG analytics and climate risk. And what we've seen so far in terms of the performance of our new hires and front office sales and our client management roles has reinforced our expectation that the benefits of that hiring activity will meaningfully accelerate in the second half, and particularly some positive trends in CRB gave us confidence in our improving growth outlook.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "e727504d-f5a3-4ee5-b017-6b98c05cc78e", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: I think looking macro, right, industry conditions remain generally favorable and our business has historically been inflated from general macro volatility, and we're certainly seeing some of that. The need for sound advice and risk management solutions typically only intensifies during dynamic times such as these in the markets, and many of our clients look to us for help in navigating changes in labor markets, financial markets, and the geopolitical environment.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "e727504d-f5a3-4ee5-b017-6b98c05cc78e", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: In H,W, C, we're seeing strong demand and growth across the H, W and C businesses. The macro environment remains reasonably supportive and the buildup of our technology offerings further enhances our resilience and reinforces our confidence in our positioning. In R&B, we think the company-specific headwinds we had are mostly behind us, and expect we'll continue to narrow that growth gap as our high reactions gain momentum.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "e727504d-f5a3-4ee5-b017-6b98c05cc78e", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Macro uncertainty is proving to be a bit of a tailwind as our clients seek to better manage their risk in a highly complex environment.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 5, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "e727504d-f5a3-4ee5-b017-6b98c05cc78e", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: So just a point of clarification, you ran through a lot of information, I appreciate that. When I think about talent rewards, I used to have a lot of economic sensitivity to it. How does that bake into your thought process as you had your fiscal year 2024 revenue targets?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory Peters", "section_number": 3, "uuid": "e4a33e02-56a3-4c51-b3d4-bdc4dc1a4044", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Raymond James"}

section.text: Greg, I'd point out two things, right? One is that the effects of COVID and new ways of working are stimulating demand for services as our client base is sort of looking to manage their workforce in light of the changes to the nature of full-time work in the gig economy. So some of the sensitivity we would have normally seen through the economic cycle, actually just hasn't been there this time.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "26c4a5d1-99cb-49b1-b77d-4a315e674723", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: And the second is we have pivoted the business over the years from a rather pure consulting and project-oriented business to be much more reliant on annuity revenue and software. So it's simply a more resilient business than in the past.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "26c4a5d1-99cb-49b1-b77d-4a315e674723", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: My second question is just on the other parts of the fiscal 2024 on the revised targets. The margin is lower, the free cash flow numbers are lower. And I was wondering if you could spend a minute and talk to us about the gives and takes on those -- the revisions to those parts of your estimates.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory Peters", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "9f64ba1d-8c39-4025-babb-577471432cd3", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Raymond James"}

section.text: Yes, sure. Greg, it's Andrew. Thanks for the question. On the margin, it is purely a function of the impact of the Russian business as well as when we think the pacing of the incremental transformation savings will come online during the three-year period. The free cash flow guide and change really has three components to it. The first is the Russian divestiture where we received no cash proceeds and also had the loss of both the revenue and cash generation from future business but also the receivables, right, that we already had accounted for, which were uncollectible.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "00cd34da-6a2b-4520-88f7-97d881187998", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: The second component was the incremental cost to achieve the $60 million of transformation program savings at the same two and a half times rate that we've been talking about. So that's an incremental $150 million. And the third component is timing differences from cash tax payments made this year on both the termination fee and Willis Re gain which our Investor Day guidance contemplated would incur entirely in 2021.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "00cd34da-6a2b-4520-88f7-97d881187998", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: As we've mentioned in our prepared remarks last quarter, part of our decrease in free cash flow this year was due to some of these tax payments taking place this year rather than when we had originally anticipated just due to some of the complexity and timing considerations.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "00cd34da-6a2b-4520-88f7-97d881187998", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Got it. Thanks for the detail.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory Peters", "section_number": 7, "uuid": "a765ec67-432a-4545-af7e-0049bf3acc6a", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Raymond James"}

section.text: Yup, perfect. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 8, "uuid": "e6259c45-d0c7-4062-a154-eb76c25db14f", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Hi, thanks. Good morning. I want to go back to the question on the guidance, right? So if I look at the operating margin in the new 2024 guidance. At the midpoint, you're lowering that by $125 million. And I know Russia right, $120 million, and it's a high-margin business, but it seems like that is higher than losing Russia. Is there something else going on there?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Elyse Greenspan", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "f5a92b27-794b-4b37-940d-c63ce282faa9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: And -- or maybe it's just that the saves are back-end loaded, but it seems like there's some other earnings that are leaving 2024 relative to your prior guide other than just Russia?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Elyse Greenspan", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "f5a92b27-794b-4b37-940d-c63ce282faa9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: Yes. I think -- Elyse, it's Andrew. I think some of the disconnect there, maybe just when you the timing of the saves -- the incremental saves are coming online. But the change in margin has really been driven purely by the impact of the Russia divestiture.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "91b959c2-96c5-42f1-9835-21360bb0c861", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Okay. And then in terms of this current quarter, right, the segment margins were both weaker, but there was lower unallocated expenses. What -- is there something going on with the corporate unallocated expenses that drove them down this quarter? And is that sustainable? Or was there just something difference between the corporate cost that you downstream to the segment this quarter versus prior periods?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Elyse Greenspan", "section_number": 12, "uuid": "9990a219-abd5-4eeb-9bd4-d3b76ab4cef0", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: Yes. Our margin expansion in the quarter was driven by the benefits of our transformation program savings and also some strategic portfolio management actions which were more than offset by some of the increased investments in talent seen at the segment level. We had corporate savings as well, but just not necessarily the same level of reinvestment that you would have seen within the segments.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 13, "uuid": "fed868b8-6818-4ac0-80b2-5944dc4f44c0", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: There is also the impact of some of these businesses that we decided to exit coming out of the deal termination, which are not allocated to the new segments as well as the effective management of the stranded costs from the Willis Re divestiture.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 13, "uuid": "fed868b8-6818-4ac0-80b2-5944dc4f44c0", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Are most of the Willis Re stranded cost gone at this point?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Elyse Greenspan", "section_number": 14, "uuid": "9abea546-41f1-464a-93ff-4ac900ef3e5e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: I'd say they're being effectively managed given that we are still in the midst of a transition services agreement with Gallagher.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 15, "uuid": "b55839d0-a867-4c50-8bc3-63a848405654", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Okay, thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Elyse Greenspan", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "a230ba5c-a9b4-4f58-92e3-1b2d351f7f00", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: Hi, good morning. Sorry to beat a dead horse, but I got kind of confused here following your answer to Elyse's question about these expenses impacting the 2024 guidance. So is it the idea that we're ahead of taking cost cuts, but those cost cuts are happening sometime at a later time, perhaps, perhaps beyond 2024, and that's affecting this guidance? And I apologize for my confusion.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Newsome", "section_number": 18, "uuid": "720b6d80-e108-488a-b650-921a399c47bf", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Piper Sandler"}

section.text: Yes. No problem, Paul. I was referring to the incremental $60 million that we announced on top of the initial $300 million. So it was really about the pacing of the incremental $60 million.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 19, "uuid": "14d1b6c5-9a34-44a1-a69c-edfd98d4256d", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: And that's happening sort of after 2024, so it's not helping the 2024 as much as we would expect?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Newsome", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "f9784505-42dc-454e-81b2-ec2417bb59d1", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Piper Sandler"}

section.text: I think that's the right way to think about it. It will be more weighted towards the back end of the program rather than during the current period or near term.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "73246a4b-ff18-4787-97f2-5266492d4392", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Which I think, Paul, is something you'd expect by savings that we've identified later in the process.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 22, "uuid": "b6d70119-5914-4c22-bfd4-e4f3e31caaea", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: No, that makes sense. I think we're still struggling a little bit with the math because of the -- it looked like there was quite a bit more than the Russian loss in the event, which is high, but it also looked like there was sort of less of an impact from the cost cutting. So I guess I'm still -- I apologize again for my confusion, but it just doesn't seem like the numbers are adding quite the same, like maybe there's something else in there that we or just missing, but again I apologize for my confusion.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Newsome", "section_number": 23, "uuid": "cf3a4af0-6a1a-4bde-88f7-005596cabc76", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Piper Sandler"}

section.text: Yes. No. I think you just need to be thinking about the margin on the Russian business in the appropriate fashion and you can triangulate on the reguide on the margin.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 24, "uuid": "ae38af04-8610-4cd8-8080-00e41bf6a73f", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: I'll do that, thank you very much. Appreciate your help.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Newsome", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "87e882c0-2c91-48bb-8122-eb113c1fa722", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Piper Sandler"}

section.text: I just wanted to go back to the margin target reduction, the one point reduction. Maybe we could just put some numbers around Russia, some specific numbers because I'm sort of calculating it being a 30 to 40 basis point adverse impact on the margin, so there's a bit more, at least, that I'm thinking is in there. So maybe if you could just clarify that. And then secondly, on the fiduciary income, I think that is something that is going to be a tailwind.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Motemaden", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "83d93575-2914-4a8d-91e3-22c9ca3bc10c", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Maybe could you just talk about how much of a benefit that, that had this quarter? And also, is that -- I think that's going to increase going forward that's going to help the margin. I'm assuming that's baked into the guide as well, but if you could just clarify that as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "David Motemaden", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "83d93575-2914-4a8d-91e3-22c9ca3bc10c", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Yes, sure. On the margin recast, the -- it's important to keep in mind that the margin on that business, as we've said, is more than double the enterprise-wide margin. So you can use that to get to the recasted margin range. And then on investment income, we haven't disclosed the specific numbers. I think you'll see some information in the queue that might be helpful in framing that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "e92c2d7e-d5e0-49fd-b9a2-67ac60fc7c5c", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: We are definitely starting to see some modest benefit from the rising rate environment, come through in the financials. But of course, as rates rise, we've got to turn over investment portfolios and that takes time to work through the system fully.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "e92c2d7e-d5e0-49fd-b9a2-67ac60fc7c5c", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Yes. I mean, back to Russia for just one second. I mean you've got to recognize, as you think about our Russian business. We have been operating there for over 40 years, right? We had a very strong position in the country. The nature of the business was largely project-based work, one-off and starts with a pretty high profit margin, but it was a minimal local presence required to service business.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 29, "uuid": "f2434fcb-22aa-454d-a144-17218e7f24c0", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: And we're able to leverage our existing global operating infrastructure on the global platform. And thus, able to do this in the country in a very cost-effective manner.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 29, "uuid": "f2434fcb-22aa-454d-a144-17218e7f24c0", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Got it. Okay. Okay. I guess it was much higher than double than, I guess, the enterprise-wide margin then much higher. Okay. That's helpful. And then maybe just switching gears on M&A. I've just noticed -- I mean, the cash balance is very high. You guys are, I think, under your leverage target by quite a bit. And yet the buyback, I think, is definitely a little bit light versus, I think, just given the cash position and the leverage profile.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Motemaden", "section_number": 30, "uuid": "1233dcbf-326a-400e-9908-c1ac4884f0a7", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: So I'm wondering if -- are you guys contemplating any larger scale M&A? Or I guess, why haven't we seen the buyback really ramp up just given the cash on the balance sheet?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "David Motemaden", "section_number": 30, "uuid": "1233dcbf-326a-400e-9908-c1ac4884f0a7", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: So I'll start on M&A, and maybe Andrew can comment a bit about buybacks. As we laid out in last year's Investor Day, intentional portfolio management to optimize value is fundamental to our Simplify initiatives, and we're still looking across our options to create value for shareholders, and that includes divestitures as well as opportunistic M&A opportunities.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "957c04b8-3689-47cc-b6e3-89dcd08c251b", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: And now that the market is finally tilting in favor of buyers of it, that should strengthen our -- look for opportunities to strengthen our capabilities in key functional areas and important geographies. But we're continuing to employ a disciplined capital allocation strategy that balances capital return with internal investments in strategic M&A to look for the highest return possibilities.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "957c04b8-3689-47cc-b6e3-89dcd08c251b", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: And just on the repurchase front, we have been pretty consistent in our messaging that share repurchases are going to come at the pace of free cash flow generally speaking, unless we find alternative uses for that. The -- I won't get into the details of the cash balance, but we do consider that cash balance as well as the free cash flow when looking at repurchases decisions as well as our financial leverage.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "6fb29a92-8078-493f-bdbc-1e12e24a8f50", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: And with rates where they are, we're very thoughtful about incremental leverage and the cost that, that comes with that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "6fb29a92-8078-493f-bdbc-1e12e24a8f50", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Got it. So I guess -- yes, so the cash target balance is kind of $1.5 billion sort of where it ended the quarter is kind of the cash level that you guys think is necessary to run at?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Motemaden", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "d5a73189-92af-43db-a611-93e9923cbc07", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: No. I don't -- I think we can run leaner than that, but we do have to keep cash on hand for future obligations as well as funding share repurchases and managing the cash flow.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "033471ef-e0d5-443a-9bc7-1f2355abf0c8", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Motemaden", "section_number": 35, "uuid": "d7970488-547d-413f-8a0e-db1c50e344ac", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 36, "uuid": "f329fc60-f037-49c8-9e6b-c24d8edee267", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Hey, thank you and good morning. I'm trying to get at net staffing in the third quarter. How did that improve incrementally? And just around that, maybe as I think Andrew talked earlier about a survey of Willis Re's where clients are seeing pricing in the aggregate up 6% on average. And then you talked about 6% organic revenue growth.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Kligerman", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "8cfa9790-058c-4882-a5cb-febefa5a1a6e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: So would, a, I interpret that meaning that your kind of client base has been very stable kind of very flattish, and the uptick in organic revenue has been largely by pricing and exposure growth? And then the part b of it is net staffing, how did that change Q-over-Q?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Andrew Kligerman", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "8cfa9790-058c-4882-a5cb-febefa5a1a6e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: So let me start with staffing. And we don't do headcount on a quarterly basis. We will discuss headcount detail in our 10-K. So hiring has been strong, and the hiring activity in Q3 matched that in the first half and it's fortified by the fact that we see the benefit of our retention efforts. Voluntary attrition has remained consistent with the macro environment and the external benchmarks we use to measure this.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "dc367842-4756-485d-8657-6c13af509aaf", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: So our year-to-date hiring has exceeded voluntary terminations. Our headcount continues to increase. And sort of getting to the revenue aspect of your question, we anticipate that the contributions we improve in our talent base to become more meaningful going forward.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "dc367842-4756-485d-8657-6c13af509aaf", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: And just on the dynamics around growth, right, there's different factors pushing and pulling in the opposite directions, right? So I think we've been pretty clear that coming out of the breakup of the transaction last year that things like retention, right, were challenged, particularly in certain geographies and certain lines of business. And of course, in the opposite direction, you have rate and new business and things of that nature. So there are offsetting factors that contribute to the organic growth profile.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 40, "uuid": "f558d2aa-4b8b-412b-8162-182cb2ab7f99", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Got it. And not to belabor too much, the issue of the EBIT revenue target change. Carl, you seem somewhat optimistic last quarter that you had some puts and takes where you really wouldn't have to worry about pressures. You seem confident that you could meet those 2022 targets for 2024.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Kligerman", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "449410c4-31b1-4e76-9740-b82834ea3b1e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: So now as you've made a change due to Russia, what I'd like to know is what would give us confidence that we're not going to see another change for the weaker? And if there is another change, what might be some of the risks that are kind of prominent in your mind right now?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Andrew Kligerman", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "449410c4-31b1-4e76-9740-b82834ea3b1e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: Yes. So when we came up with our initial targets, where we looked at a variety of scenarios to what could happen between now and 2024, right? Different economic outlooks all sorts of different things, right? I don't think we factored in that we would be divesting a business of the scope of and size of Russia for no cash proceeds to reinvest, right?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "07839d91-f02c-4aae-85ed-7698396399af", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: That, I think, is enough of a one-off that we felt justified in the transparency we're giving you on recasting targets. But I thought that we were going to have a divestment for zero, yes, was a bit outside the main term. And frankly, I think that is a bit unique and extraordinary.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "07839d91-f02c-4aae-85ed-7698396399af", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: So bottom line, you feel very confident in 2024. And then with that, that extra $60 million of expense saves, would that get you back in 2025 for that operating margin target of 24% to 25%?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Kligerman", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "3a92a8b5-ab86-4132-b090-e6df71c567f3", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: We're very pleased with the progress we're making [Technical Issues] on the expense savings, and that's one of the reasons why we said we maintained sort of the delta between starting and end to get there and we actually see more daylight developing. That's why we raised the $300 million to $360 million.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 44, "uuid": "b3343538-7ae0-4d52-af95-d32609286851", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Okay. And maybe if I could just sneak one last in. And you did -- Carl, you mentioned at the beginning, attractive opportunities for M&A. Could you give us a sense of what areas maybe that have kind of prompted to see some practice -- what pockets of your businesses might be compelling?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Kligerman", "section_number": 45, "uuid": "6602036c-9673-428f-bf7e-9a46e4c187c4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: So while I was speaking attractive, right, it was the fact that valuations appear to be coming down from levels where we just didn't think that they could be value accretive to us, right? And so -- there are opportunities across the span of the businesses we operate in. As we look to what makes sense for us, right, it's going to be, whether it's a geographic adjacency of an attractive economy that will fit our business profile.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "cf9ca652-4839-4a17-af48-ed70ca9258cd", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Or a specialty area where we see that fitting in very nicely to what we do very well in the marketplace.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "cf9ca652-4839-4a17-af48-ed70ca9258cd", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Okay, thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Kligerman", "section_number": 47, "uuid": "3337ad78-33f5-4c04-87a8-15984c9c0cd7", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: Okay, thank you. Good morning. In the Benefits Delivery and Outsourcing, some of your competitors have had to adjust their assumptions around customer longevity and here I'm talking about TRANZACT. I'm just sort of curious, your current view about your assumptions there. And then also curious your view of the competitive environment as we kind of get into enrollment season, how the competition looks in terms of the push for leads and advertising, that sort of thing?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Mark Hughes", "section_number": 49, "uuid": "212b6b87-c078-4246-8789-baafff3619a7", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Truist"}

section.text: Sure. So let me begin with the second part of that, and I'll get to the assumptions. We're quite happy with our positioning on TRANZACT and the opportunity, right? Again, this is a place where the market addressable to us, expands by 10,000 people a day. That's how many people become Medicare eligible, newly for Medicare every day. And the people who -- the percentage of people who decide to buy a Medicare Advantage plan, rather traditional Medicare continues to rise and expect it to go from 40% to over 50% by the end of the decade.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "0651249d-2ccf-466c-aad6-15f53f4ea95a", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: So there's clearly growth potential in this market. As you point out, right, there's been some volatility amongst our competitors and the carriers, and that does have some effect on us, some retention in the -- retrenchment in the market with some of our competitors, and that can impact us to our advantage. But certainly, churn in carriers books of business can impact our persistency rates.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "0651249d-2ccf-466c-aad6-15f53f4ea95a", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: But we have taken steps, right? I think that put us in a different position than most of our competitors. We fortified our lead qualification process and have set up a post-placement customer care team to make sure that people are satisfied with the coverage they're electing. And that, plus our disciplined cost management enables us, we think, to continue growing while others have to slow down to focus on their profitability.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "0651249d-2ccf-466c-aad6-15f53f4ea95a", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: With respect to persistency rates, right, this is something we examined, right, within the portfolio on a line-by-line basis. And we use independent actuaries to make sure that we're validating our team's view of what we think the persistency will be. And continue to evaluate how the market looks and what that will be.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "0651249d-2ccf-466c-aad6-15f53f4ea95a", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Appreciate it, thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Mark Hughes", "section_number": 51, "uuid": "d32194c0-3705-4c57-8b23-892d31f70dc9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Truist"}

section.text: Good morning. It's Mark Marcon from Baird. You mentioned that headcount is actually up on a sequential basis relative to Q2. Salaries and Benefits are down by 2.4% year-over-year, 2.7% sequentially. Is the primary reason why Salaries and Benefits are down on a dollar basis because of FX? And a small element of Russia, you mentioned that the presence on the ground was fairly minimal.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Mark Marcon", "section_number": 53, "uuid": "0de47aa8-1407-4370-a7fe-9d99dda4df21", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Baird"}

section.text: So I'm just trying to understand that element and to what -- what do you attribute to the decline to?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Mark Marcon", "section_number": 53, "uuid": "0de47aa8-1407-4370-a7fe-9d99dda4df21", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Baird"}

section.text: Yes. I think FX is a meaningful component of the difference that you're seeing there in that line item given where our employee bases are located.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 54, "uuid": "ce422cd3-2887-44de-9b14-c8221beaf278", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: I would add that part of our transformation program involves workforce relocation as we simplify where we do work. And so -- not front office, but a significant part of our mid- and back office hiring has occurred in our international businesses, where we tend to enjoy lower-wage structures.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 55, "uuid": "4e5399df-d96c-48ae-abcb-adae945d0a85", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: We also have the impact of our transformation program and where -- again, where folks are located and making sure that the savings are coming through, and you're seeing some of that materialize there as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 56, "uuid": "f47961c3-4bbb-43e4-87f4-6aa37b2a4926", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: And I would imagine you're also optimizing different roles and the expenses of various roles in order to optimize things from a long-term perspective. To what extent could trends continue, when we think about it just as it relates to that, if the headcount continues to go up?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Mark Marcon", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "0139e774-10db-4c5c-a500-66e87d098bf1", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Baird"}

section.text: Yes. We're always looking to make progress in that ratio. It's a constant focus for us. As I said, optimizing the workforce is a really important component of the transformation program. And hence, the comp and bend that falls out of that is an important metric.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 58, "uuid": "638f059d-9ba9-45b7-acff-96be6f83d673", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: And that's not just necessarily a location, right? That can be automation.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 59, "uuid": "0cabf2cb-3e42-44ba-8023-1f9e3aa28765", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Great. And then with regards to just going back to the prior question with regards to TRANZACT, I mean is it your general sense that based on everything that you're currently seeing out in the market that TRANZACT should be able to go back to its kind of historic level of performance? Or are there elements that would make it more like last year just because of certain vagaries in the market right now?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Mark Marcon", "section_number": 60, "uuid": "3bd4b733-749e-4e0a-9605-5a66271a5692", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Baird"}

section.text: Yes. A couple of things there. I think, one, it's important to remember that growth rates will likely moderate as that business becomes bigger and bigger. That's just the simple fact of the math. The other thing to keep in mind is that over 50% of the individual marketplace business revenues were generated in the fourth quarter. So it's best to think about that business on a full year basis, not focus on any particular quarter.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "e5866a10-cfa4-4e46-9e54-f6987cca5a58", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: We performed very strong this year and continue to feel positive about our current market positioning. And we're also encouraged by the early signs we're seeing for the quarter. But again, it's still very early in enrollment season.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "e5866a10-cfa4-4e46-9e54-f6987cca5a58", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Maybe an update on the magnitude of book settlements you might expect in 4Q and beyond because I know you've maintained the organic growth outlook for 2022, but you faced a difficult compare with the $74 million in book sales from 4Q 2021.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert Cox", "section_number": 63, "uuid": "d62cdb64-db66-4d79-8712-43d163830af0", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Yes. We still expect to see some book sales throughout the rest of the year that relates to 2021 events. We do expect those to normalize even further as 2021 receives from preview. This dynamic was anticipated in our long-term forecast for mid-single-digit growth. And as you point out and as a reminder, in Q4 of 2021, there was approximately $74 million of book sales, $39 million of that was in the segments. We do not anticipate that level to repeat this year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 64, "uuid": "0bc992a2-34bf-4a17-8dfc-1f84c1af4f1e", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Okay. And can you give us some more color on the tailwinds you're seeing in the Wealth business, particularly in the U.K. And with respect to the increase in project activity related to financial market volatility.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert Cox", "section_number": 65, "uuid": "ec50549a-eabb-409e-852c-fc751ce84b04", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Yes. So when markets fluctuate a lot, right, our client base in the Wealth business, specifically our retirement business, needs to often reforecasting of what their cash funding requirements or their accounting expense requirements are going to be. So it just generates a significant amount of project work for us in the markets where there are major defined benefit plans.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 66, "uuid": "0d225396-8538-4431-a4ae-b1d779b5f47f", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: And when the volatility stops, that work will stop, but we don't seem to have any lack of volatility these days. I'd probably offset a bit by the fact that within the Wealth business, of course, we have our investments business and a certain amount of that business is based on asset-based fees and with lower capital market levels over the year, that has been a bit of a headwind for that business.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 66, "uuid": "0d225396-8538-4431-a4ae-b1d779b5f47f", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Good morning [Indecipherable] Good morning, thanks. So two quick questions, if I can. First, I guess, one of the questions again a lot this morning in e-mail is whether there are other regions of the world where you similarly have very outsized margins that are like Russia, just in terms of understanding the scope of margin expansion program and where it does apply?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Meyer Shields", "section_number": 68, "uuid": "b1b5ab44-51df-43c6-b226-208931c0cf33", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KBW"}

section.text: So as with any diversified business, we're going to have places and lines of business that are more profitable than the group average and less profitable than group average. And so the answer is we have some, right? But are generally the areas where we have either specialist capability that's hard to replicate or that there are regulatory barriers to entry. So there is competition that might be less than open competition, are going to be areas where there may be opportunities to have higher profits than average in the business.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 69, "uuid": "4e3fec99-4d82-4271-a1e5-a67f53983ec7", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: So the answer is there are places. However, we are a broadly diversified business, right? And we do just discuss where our revenue is sourced from. And so there are many geographies where we have significant revenue concentration of the size of Russia. You can see our top five listings in 10-K.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Carl Hess", "section_number": 69, "uuid": "4e3fec99-4d82-4271-a1e5-a67f53983ec7", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Okay. That's helpful. And then just going back to TRANZACT very briefly. To because other competitors are pulling back and providing, I guess, a better opportunity for near-term growth at TRANZACT. Is that going to have a negative impact on cash flow?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Meyer Shields", "section_number": 70, "uuid": "bb175bd4-1621-4d4d-ae7b-dbf35e021af1", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KBW"}

section.text: That's a dynamic that we manage very closely, as you can imagine. So we do make sure that the growth we're targeting is profitable growth and do balance that against the cash consumption in that line of business. So we don't expect it to be a significant drag. But of course, we do manage that dynamic closely.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Krasner", "section_number": 71, "uuid": "c39a9e83-f503-47f1-8859-dbcb686e1829", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Willis Towers Watson Public"}

section.text: Okay, fantastic. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Meyer Shields", "section_number": 72, "uuid": "47a63628-3d53-47b4-b8c9-2e49906d085e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KBW"}

title: Q&A for WLTW (Willis Towers Watson Public) on 10/27/22 9:00 AM ET
